unnormalised: **Logistics Delays Hamper Manufacturing Output in Key Industrial Hubs**
normalised: **Logistics Delays Hamper Manufacturing Output in Key Industrial Hubs**

unnormalised: Mumbai, October 26, 2023 – Persistent logistics delays are significantly impacting manufacturing output across key industrial hubs like Chakan and Sriperumbudur, according to a recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII). The delays are primarily attributed to infrastructure bottlenecks at major ports like JNPT and increased road congestion, especially during the festival season leading up to Diwali.
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty six, two thousand and twenty three – Persistent logistics delays are significantly impacting manufacturing output across key industrial hubs like Chakan and Sriperumbudur, according to a recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (C I I). The delays are primarily attributed to infrastructure bottlenecks at major ports like J N P T and increased road congestion, especially during the festival season leading up to Diwali.

unnormalised: Dr. Asha Sharma, lead author of the report, stated that the delays are adding approximately 15% to transportation costs, eroding the competitiveness of Indian manufacturers. Several SMEs in sectors like textiles and auto components are facing severe challenges.
normalised: Doctor Asha Sharma, lead author of the report, stated that the delays are adding approximately fifteen percent to transportation costs, eroding the competitiveness of Indian manufacturers. Several S M E s in sectors like textiles and auto components are facing severe challenges.

unnormalised: "We are seeing delays of up to 7-10 days in shipments reaching warehouses in Delhi-NCR," said Mr. Rajiv Gupta, owner of an auto parts manufacturing unit in Gurgaon. He further added that the increased warehousing costs, averaging Rs. 50 per sq ft, are putting immense pressure on his profit margins.

unnormalised: The report recommends urgent government intervention, including improved port infrastructure and streamlined customs procedures, to alleviate the situation and ensure the smooth flow of goods across the country, preventing further disruption to the manufacturing sector. The delayed projects of the Dedicated Freight Corridor also need to be expedited, covering the remaining 3400 km.
